questions.text:
Match each type of haemorrhage with its corresponding source of bleeding and Location. Which of the following combinations is correct?

 


	
		
			
			Type of Hemorrhage
			
			
			Source of Bleeding
			
			
			Location
			
		
		
			
			a. Epidural Hemorrhage
			
			
			1. Middle meningeal artery
			
			
			i. 

			
			
		
		
			
			b. Subdural Hemorrhage
			
			
			2. Bridging veins
			
			
			ii. 

			
			
		
		
			
			c. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
			
			
			3. Cerebral arteries
			
			
			iii. 

			
			
		
		
			
			d. Intracerebral Hemorrhage
			
			
			4. Ruptured cerebral aneurysm
			
			
			iv.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) c-4-iii

Explanation:

  • Subarachnoid haemorrhage often results from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm (e.g., a berry aneurysm). It can also occur due to head trauma or arteriovenous malformations (AVMs).
  • Bleeding occurs in the subarachnoid space, which lies between the arachnoid and pia mater.

Type of Hemorrhage

Source of Bleeding

Location of Blood Collection

Symptoms

Epidural Hemorrhage

Middle meningeal artery

Between the skull bone and endosteal layer of the dura mater.



 
  • Acute symptoms, late paralysis starting with the face and spreading to the lower body
  • A lucid interval refers to a temporary period of clarity and responsiveness after a head injury, is seen in epidural hematoma, followed by a rapid neurological decline as the hematoma expands

Subdural Hemorrhage

Bridging veins (venous bleed)

Between dura mater and arachnoid mater.

Slower progression of cerebral compression, haphazard progression of paralysis.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

Rupture of small arteries (e.g., aneurysms)

Subarachnoid space at the base of the brain (cisterns)

Severe headache ("thunderclap headache"), often caused by aneurysm rupture or hypertension

Intracerebral Hemorrhage

Rupture of arteries within brain parenchyma

Brain tissue (parenchyma) itself, often in basal ganglia or cortex


 

Sudden onset of focal neurological deficits, headache, vomiting, altered consciousness.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident with severe head trauma. His GCS is 5. On examination, there is a loss of sensation below the level of the neck and flaccid paralysis of all four limbs. Which of the following structures pass through the same cranial foramen as the structure involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Spinal root of accessory nerve

Explanation:

  • The structure involved in this patient is the spinal cord, which is the continuation of the medulla oblongata, which passes through the foramen magnum, the largest foramen in the skull, located in the occipital bone. It allows for the passage of several critical structures, including:
    • Medulla Oblongata exits the skull through the foramen magnum and continues as the spinal cord.
    • Spinal roots of the spinal accessory nerve.
    • Meninges, which surround the brain and spinal cord.
    • Vertebral arteries and veins.

Labyrinthine artery (Option A) passes through the Internal acoustic meatus.

 

Internal Carotid Artery(Option B) enters the skull through the carotid canal.

 

Posterior meningeal artery (Option D) passes through the Jugular foramen.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with severe headaches and neurological deficits. Imaging reveals thrombosis of the inferior sagittal sinus. Which sinus does the inferior sagittal sinus primarily drain into?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Straight sinus

 

Explanation:

The inferior sagittal sinus drains into the straight sinus, which then continues to drain into the left transverse sinus.

Fate of Dural Sinuses:

Sinus

Features

Drainage

Superior Sagittal Sinus

Located between the two layers of the falx cerebri.

Right transverse sinus

Inferior Sagittal Sinus

Smaller channel between the lower layers of the falx cerebri

Straight Sinus

Straight Sinus

Lies in the junction of the falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli

Left transverse sinus

Transverse Sinus

Runs laterally from the internal occipital protuberance

Continuous with the Sigmoid sinus

Sigmoid Sinus

S-shaped, receiving tributaries from the mastoid & internal auditory veins.

Internal Jugular Vein

Occipital Sinus

Runs downward from the internal occipital protuberance

Confluence of Sinuses.

Sphenoparietal Sinus

Found along the lateral aspect of the sphenoid bone.

Anterior Cavernous Sinus

Superior Petrosal Sinus

Located above the petrous part of the temporal bone.

Transverse sinus

Inferior Petrosal Sinuses

Located near the base of the skull.

Internal Jugular Vein

Petrosquamous Sinus

Lies in petrosquamous suture if present.

Transverse sinus

 

Confluence of Sinuses: (Torcular Herophili)

A significant anatomical structure located at the posterior part of the skull, near the internal occipital protuberance & serves as a junction where several major dural venous sinuses meet and drain into one another.

Components:

  • Superior Sagittal Sinus: Drains venous blood from the cerebral hemispheres.
  • Straight Sinus: Formed by the union of the inferior sagittal sinus and the great cerebral vein, draining deeper structures of the brain.
  • Occipital Sinus: A small sinus that runs along the posterior aspect of the falx cerebelli, draining into the confluence.

questions.text: A 34 y/o male presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He complains of difficulty in chewing and numbness over the lower jaw. Upon examination, he has weakness in the muscles of mastication. Which of the following structures do not course along with the nerve implicated in the patient's symptoms through the same cranial foramen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vidian’s nerve

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms indicate mandibular nerve (V3) involvement, as it innervates the muscles of mastication and provides sensory function to the lower face. This nerve exits through the foramen ovale.
  • The Vidian nerve, formed by the union of the greater petrosal nerve and the deep petrosal nerve, passes through the anterior wall of the foramen lacerum.

 

Structures that traverse foramen ovale (Mnemonic: MALE)

  • Mandibular nerve (Option B).
  • Accessory meningeal artery (Option C).
  • Lesser petrosal nerve (Option A).
  • Emissary vein
  • Occasionally, the Anterior trunk of the middle meningeal vein

At times, there is a canaliculus innominatus situated between the foramen ovale and the foramen spinosum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with numbness in his upper lip and cheek, along with difficulty sensing temperature changes, following a dental procedure. Through which of the following marked structures does the affected nerve pass?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) D

 

Explanation:

The nerve affected in the given scenario is the Maxillary nerve, which passes through the foramen rotundum in the middle cranial fossa.

Foramen of Middle Cranial Fossa

Structures Passing through

Foramen Rotundum

Maxillary Nerve

Foramen Ovale (Option C)
  • Mandibular nerve
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary vein
  • Occasionally, the Anterior trunk of the middle meningeal vein

Foramen Spinosum (Option B)
  • Middle meningeal artery and vein,
  • Emissary vein
  • Nervus spinosus(Meningeal branch of mandibular nerve)

Foramen Lacerum (Option A)

A triangular opening at the base of the skull, but in living individuals, it is filled with cartilage, and no major structures pass through it.

  • Foramen lacerum contributed by 3 bones-temporal, occipital and sphenoid
  • The internal carotid artery and nerve plexus traverse its superior end;
  • The nerve to the pterygoid canal passes through its anterior wall.
  • The meningeal branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery and an emissary vein pass through it.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to the formation of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Greater wing of the sphenoid

 

Explanation:

  • The marked area is Pterion, located at the anterolateral fontanelle and is formed by the union of
    • Frontal bone
    • Parietal bone
    • Squamous temporal bones &
    • Greater wing of the sphenoid.

  • At birth, this area is filled with a membrane, which typically closes by around 2 months of age, though it can sometimes be delayed until 6 months.
  • The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery runs beneath the Pterion and Stem of lateral sulcus .
  • Injury to this area can result in extradural or epidural haemorrhage.
  • The pterion is a frequent location for trephination (creating an opening in the skull) during surgical procedures.

 

Lesser wing of sphenoid (Option A) helps separate the anterior and middle cranial fossae and serves as an attachment point for various muscles and ligaments.

Maxilla (Option B) is a paired facial bone that forms the upper jaw and holds the upper teeth.

Zygomatic bone (Option C) also known as the cheekbone, provides support for the muscles involved in facial expressions and chewing.

questions.text: A 25 y/o male presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He was initially unconscious but regained full consciousness shortly afterward, reporting only a mild headache. On examination, the patient starts to experience drowsiness, and eventually loses consciousness again. A CT scan was performed, what is the most likely source of her bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Middle meningeal artery

 

Explanation:

Findings of CT with biconvex hyperdense shadow indicate Epidural Hematoma and the most likely source for this bleeding is the Middle Meningeal artery (MMA) (Commonly Anterior division at level of pterion) This is a surgical emergency.

 

Middle Meningeal artery :

  • It is a branch of the first part of the maxillary artery, originating in the infratemporal fossa.
  • It enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen spinosum and splits into frontal and parietal branches by grooving at the temporal bone.
  • It mainly supplies small branches to the dura mater and, within the cranial cavity, further divides into
    • Trigeminal ganglion
    • Greater petrosal nerve
    • Tensor tympani
    • Temporal branches
    • An anastomotic branch
    • It holds surgical importance as it can be torn in head injuries, as it can be torn in head injuries, often involving the frontal or anterior branch, leading to extradural haemorrhage.
  • A lucid interval refers to a temporary period of clarity and responsiveness after a head injury, typically seen in epidural hematoma, followed by a rapid neurological decline as the hematoma expands and compresses the brain.

Emissary veins (Option A) serve as a venous link between intracranial and extracranial spaces, which can contribute to subdural haemorrhage.

 

Rupture of a berry aneurysm (Option B) causes subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH), with the most likely cause being persistent hypertension.


Diploic veins (Option C) begin within the two tables of the skull, with four veins on each side, and can contribute to subdural or extradural haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled hypertension presents with sudden severe headache, blurred vision, slurred speech, and right-sided weakness. A CT scan shows an acute haemorrhage in the basal ganglia. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Charcot–Bouchard aneurysm

 

Explanation:

  • Charcot–Bouchard aneurysms are small microaneurysms that develop in the penetrating arteries, particularly in regions such as the basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, and cerebellum.
  • They are strongly associated with chronic hypertension and are a common cause of intracerebral haemorrhage, often resulting from the rupture of deep-seated arteries in the brain tissue.
  • The lenticulostriate branches (LSA) of the middle cerebral artery are commonly affected, leading to:
    • Sudden onset headache
    • Contralateral hemiplegia or hemianesthesia
    • Aphasia
    • Visual disturbances
    • Vomiting


 

Berry aneurysms (Option A) are larger aneurysms located at the bifurcations of major cerebral arteries.

  • Rupture of these aneurysms can lead to subarachnoid haemorrhage, often associated with hypertension, causing bleeding between the arachnoid and pia mater.
  • This condition typically presents as an extremely severe headache, often described as the worst headache of one's life.


 

Mycotic aneurysm (Option B) is caused by infection, often associated with endocarditis or other systemic infections, leading to weakened vessel walls and aneurysm formation. It presents with fever, localised pain, inflammation, and headaches.

 

Rupture arteriovenous malformation (Option C) may cause intracerebral hemorrhage but is less strongly associated with chronic hypertension and typically affects younger individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations of structures passing through the posterior cranial fossa is incorrectly matched with their corresponding openings?

choices.text: Spinal cord, vertebral arteries – Foramen Magnum
Glossopharyngeal nerve, vagus nerve – Jugular Foramen
Facial nerve, vestibulocochlear nerve – Internal acoustic meatus
Hypoglossal nerve, emissary vein – Hypoglossal Canal

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Spinal cord, vertebral arteries – Foramen Magnum

Explanation:

The medulla passes through the Foramen Magnum and then continues as the spinal cord

Structures passing through the posterior cranial fossa

Opening

Structures

Foramen Magnum
  • Medulla oblongata
  • Meninges (dura, arachnoid, pia mater)
  • Vertebral arteries and veins
  • Spinal accessory nerve (Spinal root ascends)
  • Spinal arteries

Jugular Foramen
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve
  • Vagus nerve
  • Spinal accessory nerve (Cranial and Spinal root)
  • Internal jugular vein (exits skull here)
  • Sigmoid sinus

Internal Acoustic Meatus
  • Facial nerve
  • Vestibulocochlear nerve
  • Nervus intermedius
  • Labyrinthine arteries and veins

Hypoglossal Canal
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • The meningeal branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Emissary vein from the basilar plexus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the course of the spinal accessory nerve is TRUE?

choices.text: Passes through the internal acoustic meatus before innervating the trapezius muscle.
Exits the skull via the jugular foramen alongside the vagus nerve.
Passes through the foramen rotundum with the maxillary nerve.
Originates from the dorsal horn of C1 to C5/6 spinal cord segments.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Exits the skull via the jugular foramen alongside the vagus nerve.

 

Explanation:

The spinal accessory nerve exits the skull via the jugular foramen, travelling within the same dural sheath as the vagus nerve, separated by a fold of arachnoid mater.

Course of the spinal accessory nerve

Origin and Ascent within the Spinal Cord
  • Arises from motor neurons in the lateral aspect of the ventral horn of the cervical spinal cord (C1/2 to C5/6).
  • Rootlets combine to form the spinal accessory nerve trunk, ascend within the vertebral canal and enter the skull through the foramen magnum,

Intracranial Course
  • Inside the skull, the nerve turns upward and moves laterally toward the jugular foramen.
  • Travels through the jugular foramen in the same dural sheath as the vagus nerve, separated by a fold of arachnoid mater.

Extracranial Course and Branching
  • Exits the jugular foramen.
  • Crossed by the occipital artery as it descends obliquely, running medial to the styloid process, stylohyoid muscle, and posterior belly of the digastric.
  • Travels with the superior sternocleidomastoid branch of the occipital artery to the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and forms an anastomosis with C2 and C3 nerve fibres.

Path to the Trapezius Muscle
  • Emerges from the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  • Crosses the posterior triangle of the neck, lying on top of the levator scapulae and may divide into a plexus on the deep surface of the trapezius muscle, receiving contributions from C2-C4.

Innervation
  • Sole motor supply to the sternocleidomastoid muscle
  • Provides motor innervation to the upper and middle parts of the trapezius muscle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes surgery for a suspected brain mass. During the operation, the surgeon identifies a dural fold extending between the cerebellum and the occipital lobes, creating a partition in the cranial cavity. Which dural fold is being described?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tentorium cerebelli

Explanation:

  • The tentorium cerebelli is a horizontal structure that separates the cerebellum from the occipital lobes.
  • It extends across the posterior cranial fossa, attaching to the clinoid processes of the sphenoid bone and the inner surface of the occipital bone, thereby creating a partition between these regions.


 

Falx cerebri (Option A) separates the left and right cerebral hemispheres and contains the superior sagittal sinus along its upper margin.

Falx cerebelli (Option B) separates the cerebellar hemispheres and contains the occipital sinus within its posterior margin.

Diaphragma sellae (Option C) forms a roof over the pituitary gland, containing an opening through which the infundibulum passes.

questions.text: Which of the following sinuses is NOT located between the meningeal and endosteal layers of the dura mater?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inferior sagittal sinus

 

Explanation:

The inferior sagittal sinus is found between two meningeal layers in the free edge of the falx cerebri and not between the meningeal and endosteal layer of the dura.

 

Dural venous sinuses:

  • Large, blood-filled spaces located within the dura mater of the cranial cavity & drain venous blood from the brain and the skull.
  • Formation:
    • Separation of Dura Layers: They arise from the separation of the two layers of the dura mater—endosteal and meningeal layers.
    • Reduplication of Meningeal Layer: Some sinuses are formed by a duplication of the meningeal layer.
  • Dural folds are formed by the folding of the meningeal layer and project into the cranial cavity.
    • Falx Cerebri: Extends vertically between the two cerebral hemispheres & contains the superior and inferior sagittal sinuses.
    • Tentorium Cerebelli: A horizontal fold that separates the cerebellum from the occipital lobes of the cerebrum. It contains the transverse sinuses along its margins.
    • Falx Cerebelli: Lies between the two cerebellar hemispheres & contains Occipital sinus.

The Inferior sagittal sinus and the Straight sinus are not located between the meningeal and endosteal layers of the dura mater. The inferior sagittal sinus is found in the free edge of the falx cerebri & straight sinus is located at the junction of the falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with double vision and drooping eyelids. An MRI reveals involvement of the cavernous sinus, prompting the neurologist to evaluate the cranial nerves associated with this structure. Which of the following nerves is not a content of the cavernous sinus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mandibular nerve

 

Explanation:

The cavernous sinus contains the oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve, ophthalmic nerve, maxillary nerve, and abducens nerve.

 

The mandibular nerve does not pass through the cavernous sinus; it exits the skull via the foramen ovale.

 

Cavernous Sinus:

  • Large venous space located on either side of the Sphenoid body & Sella turcica.
  • Interior of the sinus is divided into smaller compartments (caverns) by trabeculae.
  • The floor is formed by the endosteal layer of the dura mater & lateral wall, roof, and medial wall are formed by the meningeal layer.
  • Relations:

Superior

Optic chiasma, optic tract, internal carotid artery, anterior perforated substance.

Inferior

Foramen lacerum, junction of the body and greater wing of the sphenoid.

Medial

Pituitary gland (hypophysis cerebri), sphenoid air sinus.

Lateral

Temporal lobe (uncus), cavum trigeminale containing the trigeminal ganglion.

Anterior

Superior orbital fissure, apex of the orbit.

Posterior

Crus cerebri of the midbrain, apex of the petrous temporal bone.

  • Contents:

Structures present in the Lateral Wall

Structures passing through the sinus

Superior to Inferior:

  • Oculomotor nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • Ophthalmic nerve
  • Maxillary nerve
  • Internal Carotid Artery: Surrounded by a sympathetic nerve plexus.
  • Abducent Nerve runs alongside the artery. It is first involved in cavernous sinus thrombosis. Thus abduction defect is the earliest clinical sign observed.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with symptoms of cavernous sinus thrombosis, including severe headache, visual disturbances, and facial swelling. Which of the following is not a tributary of the cavernous sinus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Deep facial vein

 

Explanation:

The deep facial vein typically drains the face and communicates with the internal jugular vein rather than entering the cavernous sinus.

 

Tributaries of the Cavernous Sinus:

The cavernous sinus receives blood from three primary sources:

From the Orbit
  • Superior ophthalmic vein (Option A)
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein (Option B)
  • Central vein of the retina (occasionally)

From the Meninges
  • Sphenoparietal sinus (Option C)
  • Anterior trunk of the middle meningeal vein

From the Brain
  • Superficial middle cerebral vein
  • A few inferior cerebral veins

 

Communications of the Cavernous Sinus:

  • Transverse sinus (via superior petrosal sinus)
  • Internal jugular vein (via inferior petrosal sinus)
  • Pterygoid venous plexus (via emissary veins through foramen ovale, foramen lacerum, and emissary sphenoidal foramen)
  • Facial vein through
    • Superior ophthalmic vein → angular vein → facial vein
    • Emissary veins → pterygoid venous plexus → deep facial vein → facial vein
  • The dangerous area of the face refers to the triangular region that stretches from the corners of the mouth to the bridge of the nose.
  • This area is clinically significant because infections in this region can potentially spread to the brain due to communication with cavernous sinus.

Boundaries:

  • Superior boundary: Bridge of the nose.
  • Lateral boundaries: Extends to the corners of the mouth.
  • Base: Upper lip.

  • Opposite cavernous sinuses (via anterior and posterior intercavernous sinuses)
  • Superior sagittal sinus (via superficial middle cerebral vein & superior anastomotic vein)
  • Internal vertebral venous plexus (via basilar venous plexus)

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient is evaluated for chronic headaches and altered mental status. A CT scan reveals potential thrombosis in an unpaired dural sinus. Which of the following sinus is unpaired?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Superior sagittal sinus

 

Explanation:

The superior sagittal sinus is an unpaired sinus located along the midline of the brain while others are paired sinuses, which exist in two symmetrical halves.

 

Dural Venous Sinuses:

  • These are channels that drain blood from the brain and are located between the layers of the dura mater.
  • They can be classified as 7 Paired & 7 Unpaired.

 

Unpaired Sinuses:

Unpaired Sinuses

Superior Sagittal Sinus
  • Located along the midline, running from the front of the skull to the back.
  • It collects blood from the brain's superficial structures.

Inferior Sagittal Sinus
  • Runs parallel to the superior sagittal sinus but is smaller and located lower.
  • It drains blood from the deep structures of the brain.

Straight Sinus
  • Formed by the junction of the inferior sagittal sinus and the great cerebral vein.
  • It drains into the confluence of sinuses.

Occipital Sinus
  • Located in the posterior cranial fossa, it drains the posterior part of the brain.

Anterior Intercavernous Sinus
  • Connects the two cavernous sinuses at the front, allowing for communication between them.

Posterior Intercavernous Sinus
  • Connects the cavernous sinuses at the back, also facilitating inter-sinus communication.

Basilar Venous Plexus
  • Drains blood from the brainstem and parts of the cerebellum.


 

Paired Sinuses:

Paired Sinuses

Transverse Sinus

Located on either side of the brain, they drain blood from the superior sagittal sinus to the sigmoid sinuses.

Sigmoid Sinus

Continuations of the transverse sinuses, curve down to drain into the internal jugular veins.

Superior Petrosal Sinus

Located above the petrous part of the temporal bone, they drain blood from the cavernous sinus to the transverse sinuses.

Inferior Petrosal Sinus

Located near the base of the skull, they drain blood from the cavernous sinus directly into the internal jugular vein.

Sphenoparietal Sinus

Found along the lateral aspect of the sphenoid bone.

Cavernous Sinus

Paired structures located on either side of the sella turcica & contain cranial nerves and the internal carotid artery.

Petrosquamous Sinus

Lies in petrosquamous suture if present & drains into the transverse sinus.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic with symptoms of hydrocephalus and developmental delays. An MRI reveals a malformation of a vein associated with increased intracranial pressure. Which of the following veins primarily contributes to its formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Internal cerebral veins

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario with the given image findings indicates a Vein of Galen malformation, which involves the abnormal dilation of the vein formed by the union of the internal cerebral veins.
  • In malformations, abnormal connections and dilations can occur, leading to significant clinical symptoms and complications such as hydrocephalus, developmental delays, seizures, congestive heart failure, headaches, neurological deficits.

Great Cerebral Vein (Vein of Galen):

  • Single vessel
  • Formed by union of thalamostriate, choroidal and septal vein, located beneath and posterior to the splenium of the corpus callosum.
  • Shortly after its formation, it receives blood from the two basal veins.
  • Finally, it joins the inferior sagittal sinus to create the straight sinus.

Tributaries of the Great Cerebral Vein:

  • Internal cerebral veins
  • Basal veins
  • Veins from the colliculi (tectum of the midbrain)
  • Veins draining the cerebellum and adjacent regions of the occipital lobes of the cerebrum.
